body.p: What to say about the year 2025? Mostly variations on the same theme as other parts of the 2020s. The same pattern of occasional expeditions to Mauritius or (mostly) France in the intervals of medical appointments and family gatherings; the same occasional excursion. I continued to pootle around with Victorian dramas, giving rise to occasional blog postings, and even the occasional academic conference. Some highlights are listed below.

January On the 11th we went back to Oxford, overnighting at the Easy Hotel in Summertown before joining the throng celebrating Hazel's 80th birthday. Back in Bristol we were taken for an outing to Kings Weston House by Pam and Philip: nice architecture, though the cake shop was not as fancy as we had been led to believe. I was rather impressed by T. Chalamet's performance as the young Bob Dylan in a movie called "A complete unknown", showing at the luxurious Everyman cinema on Whiteladies Rd. I was so much older then.

February On the 8th we escaped to Mauritius for a month or so, staying in two different beach hotels, and a third floor flat flat in Curepipe. We experienced a tropical storm called Garance, my first such experience: full details are in my holiday report

March Our arrival back in Bristol on the 3rd was fairly horrible, mostly because of the journey but also because as we staggered out of the bus station in search of the Uber, L realised she had left her phone and kindle on the bus now heading off to Newport. This led to much to and fro with the Flixbus website and with assorted insurance companies, but culminated in a trip to Newport on the 28th where she was reunited with her gadgets, and I saw some rather splendid monuments commemorating the Newport Raising of 1839. We need more chartists.

April For our first French trip of the year, we tried catching a flight from Bristol to Bordeaux on 6th, and staying the night there before taking the 1026 TER to Limoges (arr 1248), proceeding via another TER to Gueret arriving just in time for the 1430 TAD. But what we did for the four weeks in La Vergne before catching the train back to England, I have no idea.

At the start of May, I went to Oxford for a college reunion: a Gaudy lunch at Balliol. This was surprisingly enjoyable: the food was good and both Carl Schmidt and Nick Shrimpton allowed me to drone on about Lacy at them. And people I did not remember at all seemed to remember me, which is curiously satisfying. Later in the month, we had a pleasant excursion to Bath with P&P to see Opera Luna's version of the Mikado, which I also enjoyed. And at the very end of the month, we tried the other route into France, viz train to Portsmouth (the caribbean resto opposite the station is actually quite good), and the late afternoon ferry to Ouistreham, where we stayed a couple of nights in the Hotel "Le Cosy Riva Bella", enabling us to explore the beach a bit.

June From Ouistreham, we proceeded by bus and train to Coutances, and then by bus from there to La Haye where Jef and Nicole came to meet us. We stayed in a slightly odd Air BNB in La Haye, and did some seaside expeditions with Jef, still in his corset. On the 5th, we left them at Valognes and took the train to La Souterraine, via (inevitably) Paris, where we had ample time for a (very) late lunch.
JulyWe spent the whole month in La Vergne, doing nothing in particular, and then back to Bristol via La Souterraine and Paris.

August We visited Nottingham, and Maryland, the latter on 0 Aug being notable for Daphne's birthday bowling party at Stratford. Belinda and co passed through on their way to Cornwall, and we vacated the house to put them up, which gave us an excuse to sample Channings hotel (pretty good breakfast). At the end of the month, I flew off to Berlin all on my own in order to participate in the Dracor Summit at the Free University of Berlin. Very exciting.

September Was in Berlin until the 5th, when I took the slow route back to La Vergne, via Mannheim, Karlsruhe, Paris, and La Souterraine, On the 20th, I left for Bristol via Paris, again. On the 27th Kev had a surprise 50th birthday party in a pub in Easton.

October On the 14th I nipped off to Caen, by train, for a meeting of the CAESAR council, which was fun, though the hotel was noisy. Being in France, I was then unable to resist the temptation of another lengthy train journey, from Caen to Tours , Tours to Vierzon, and Vierzon to La Souterraine, of course, arriving 2021, where Patrice came (eventually) to collect me. Then I had a week or so in La Vergne, all alone, before having to repeat most of the same journey in reverse, to get back to Tours in time to teach "TEI Niveau 1" from the 27th to the 29th. And back to London and Bristol on the 30th.

NovemberFrom the 6th to the 8th I stayed in a little room in one of the many minimalist hotels around Kings Cross. The occasion was a study day on the 7th, where I met and tried to impress some of the victorian studies glitterati. Organised by the Caen Punch Project, the day was hosted at the BL, even though there was a strike going on. And at the end of the month, I yet again popped over to Caen by Eurostar, this time for the MRSH Scientific Committee. But I did not proceed from there to La Vergne, and was back in Bristol for the 22nd.

December Which was just as well, since on the 5th, L fell over in mysterious circumstances on the way home, fracturing her clavicule, Which meant that almost all amusements planned for December had to be cancelled. On the plus side, I got to know the route to and from the BRI rather well; the NHS was wonderful, and we were able to have an Xmas lunch with Elizabeth and co, a boxing day amusement with everyone except Belinda and co, and a new years eve with Belinda's boys.
